Caption: Figure 2: Example network : access graph induced from Java classes in the Resyn Assistant API. Edges have been coloured according to an application metric speciﬁc to Resyn.
Figure 1: Statistical density function computed from metric values associated with nodes or edges of a network.
Figure 3: A 2D scatterplot displaying how the strength and appli- cation speciﬁc metric distribute over the edges of the network in Figure 2.
Figure 4: Convoluting the image in Figure 3 with a Gaussian ﬁlter produces a blurring eﬀect and helps localize the regions of interest in the scatterplot.
Figure 5: A greater value of s creates wider patches (when compared with Figure 4). The shape of the nested strips extends from the existing subregions.
Figure 8: Close-up view of the scatterplot of Figure 6, with an in- crease in s. This time, a simple click triggered the selection of a whole cluster (connected sub-component).
Figure 7: Selecting the three “hub” actors (Cruise, Carrey and Diaz) on the left view highlights their corresponding subregions or patches in the blurred scatterplot (right panel).
Figure 6: Darker patches in the scatterplot can be selected to recover the package structure of the Resyn Assistant API.
Figure 10: Exploring a protein-protein interaction network based on a scatterplot showing how the co-citation metric relates to the degree of nodes.
Figure 9: Close-up view of the scatterplot obtained from the eigen- vector metric together with the clustering index computed on the IMDB network.
